content.webTitle: Phil Daoust: Radio pick of the day

fields.headline: Pick of the day
fields.bodyText: More than 20 years after that nice Mrs Thatcher did her best to destroy the coal-mining industry, the black stuff is staging a major comeback. Demand and prices have shot up, while companies are scrambling to start new opencast mines and even re-open deep-level pits. Not only is the government right behind them, there's even a plan to build Britain's first new coal-fired power station for 35 years. If the Kingsnorth plant in Kent gets the go-ahead, a wave of vast new coal-fired plants could follow. All of which has environmentalists hopping mad. Business secretary John Hutton has accused them of "gesture politics". But, they argue, the "clean" technology that is needed to deal with emissions is at least 10 years away and may never work. Julian O'Halloran investigates in File On 4 (8pm, Radio 4). Alkarim Jivani, meanwhile, is exploring the lure of The Original (11.30am, Radio 4), whether it's jeans like Levi's Originals, an estate agent's "original features" or an original work of art. What's so bad about knock-offs and reproductions, and why is homage good and plagiarism bad?
